item.title: Comment on Friday assorted links by mkt42
item.description:
"1. One list of the most cited philosophers."

They looked only at the Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy. So this is not really a list of "the most cited philosophers" as Tyler claims, instead it's a measure of the interests or prejudices of the editors of that Stanford encyclopedia.

Which could be interesting if one is interested in what those editors think. But I think the standard more wide-ranging weighted citation indices are more useful and interesting.

This study doesn't have to tackle the tricky problem of weighting, because they can treat all citations as equal within an encyclopedia. But that's a heavy tradeoff; they're looking at a very narrow universe of citations.

item.title: Comment on Jake Seliger is Dead by Adam
item.description:
Reply to rayward:

Suffering only ends with death. And the promise of resurrection and eternal bliss. Cancer has killed my closest relatives and friends, young and old alike. I'm not sure which is worse: dying by cancer when young and before a long life of suffering or dying by cancer when old after a lifetime of suffering, cancer such a cruel way to end one's long journey through this life. Are the lucky ones those who die young? I recently lost a life-long friend, whose positivity belied a lifetime of suffering, suffering as a child when he nearly burned to death, suffering as a young adult and for the remainder of his life after getting hepatitis from eating shell fish and permanent liver damage, suffering through a long battle with a blood cancer through conventional and unconventional therapy that zapped his strength, and the final insult the brain cancer that killed him. And through it all he was the johnny appleseed who sought out the suffering to spread his good cheer and never-ending positivity. But to Tabarrok it's the FDA's fault, if only the FDA allowed drug makers the freedom to choose, then no more suffering. Sometimes I think that Tabarrok is a pod person, an original A.I. I suffer emotionally from the loss throughout my life of so many close relatives and friends from the scourge of cancer. The FDA didn't cause it and the FDA can't fix it. Suffering are us. The very idea that suffering can be cured is preposterous.

Forget the resurrection and eternal bliss. Even experiencing that for trillions of years has to be fatiguing.

I wouldn't want to get rid of disgust. If we did that, I feel like people would be way more promiscuous than they already are, and would be much less picky about their sex partners and practices. item.title: Comment on My excellent Conversation with Paul Bloom by disagree
item.description:
" Well, I’ll ask a question, and a lot of guests think it’s high status simply to signal empathy rather than giving a substantive answer. The signaling-empathy answers I find quite uninteresting, and I think a lot of my listeners do, too."

It's an interesting choice and as he states at the start of every episode, it's his interview and he'll ask the questions he wants, so no problem.

But human conversation is a highly evolved, silky thing, and trying to reroute it is going to grind some gears.

And interpreting conversation through a lens of "well that's just lower value signaling and I'm seeking higher plane truth" - that's quite a hubris filter to pass through.

It's one of the great daily failures here, the belief that there's always one superior answer, and only malignantly wrong alternatives. It's good election posturing, and bad for governance and nearly everything else.

To his credit, Tyler doesn't flog this view quite as extensively as others, and I think has at least a benevolent view towards lesser mortals.

item.title: Comment on My excellent Conversation with Paul Bloom by clara b. jones
item.description:
Tyler: i don't think your audience overestimates your intelligence at all ... i would call your verbal, analytical, & other "deep" production, "stunning" ... i recognize that your capacities for clarity, profundity, "context," & breadth are facilitated by remarkable fast reading & retention traits ... it seems to me that you often downplay the role of genetics [G x E] as an explanatory variable for behavioral & "social" factors, however, your traits no doubt are enhanced by a significant biological component [i.e., genetics explaining much of the variance in your performance as per Behavioral Genetics] ... as for Paul Bloom, i don't find him "intelligent" at all ... he has the smug mien of a person with high self-regard because of his capacity as a random-word generator, as well as his ability to convince others that he has something meaningful & important to say ... further, he is part of a movement ["Cognitive Psychology"] that has all but destroyed scientific Psychology [Behaviorism, Experimental Psychology, search for patterns, unpacking variability, search for general laws, use of higher-order quantitative methods such as math modeling, experimentation, quantitative rather than verbal theory] ... the field of Psychology, because of professors like Paul Bloom, has all but returned to Philosophy & a neo-Cartesian belief system ... i call it Scala Naturae Academics ["Social Science"] ... William James & "Dick" Neisser are their "gods;" but, the Father of Psychology is Wilhelm Wundt [1859]--for mostly political reasons, Wundt, a German, is barely mentioned any longer--not even in many History of Psychology textbooks ... it is all tragic, though somewhat amusing, also ... Paul Bloom is a perpetrator of this scam ... Psychology, for the most part is no longer a Science, though, some practitioners are fighting back by way of the emerging field, Machine Psychology [AI, "machine learning," "reinforcement learning"] ...
